title: Noj tutorials
text:
This is part of the Scicloj Clojure Data Scrapbook.

1 Preface
Noj (short for Scinojure) is an opinionated way to use the emerging Clojure data stack. It collects a few of the relevant libraries together and addes some layers of composition on top of them.

source: projects/noj/notebooks/index.clj

title: 2  Machine learning - DRAFT
text:
2.1 Linear regression
We will explore the Iris dataset:
_unnamed [5 5]:

(def additive-pipeline
  (ml/pipeline
   (mm/set-inference-target :sepal-length)
   (mm/drop-columns [:species])
   {:metamorph/id :model}
   (mm/model {:model-type :smile.regression/ordinary-least-square})))



(def evaluations
  (ml/evaluate-pipelines
   [additive-pipeline]
   (ds/split->seq datasets/iris :holdout)
   ml/rmse
   :loss
   {:other-metrices [{:name :r2
                      :metric-fn fastmath.stats/r2-determination}]}))



(-> evaluations
    flatten
    first
    :fit-ctx
    :model
    ml/thaw-model)


Linear Model:

sepal-width         0.6599     0.0863     7.6500     0.0000 ***
petal-length        0.7003     0.0701     9.9877     0.0000 ***
petal-width        -0.5694     0.1585    -3.5924     0.0005 ***

title: 3  Exploring ggplot - DRAFT
text:
3.1 Setup
We will use ClojisR to call R from Clojure.
Loading ggplot2:
The base R library:

title: 3  Exploring ggplot - DRAFT
text:
(ns ggplot
  (:require [clojisr.v1.r :as r :refer [r r$ r->clj]]
            [clojisr.v1.applications.plotting :as plotting]
            [scicloj.kindly.v4.kind :as kind]
            [clojure.walk :as walk]
            [tablecloth.api :as tc]))



(r/library "ggplot2")


[1] "ggplot2"   "Rserve"    "stats"     "graphics"  "grDevices" "utils"    
[7] "datasets"  "methods"   "base"     




(r/require-r '[base])

title: 3  Exploring ggplot - DRAFT
text:
3.2 An example plot
Here is how we may generate and display a plot:

(-> "(ggplot(mpg, aes(cty, hwy, color=factor(cyl)))
         + geom_point()
         + stat_smooth(method=\"lm\")
         + facet_wrap(~cyl))"
    r
    plotting/plot->svg
    kind/html)

title: 3  Exploring ggplot - DRAFT
text:
3.3 Representing plots as Clojure data
Inspired by cxplot’s internal ggplot.as.list finction, let us represent ggplot objects as R data structures. A ggplot object is an R list of ggproto objects. We recursively unwrap this structure and convert it to Clojure.

(defn ggolot->clj
  ([r-obj
    options]
   (ggolot->clj r-obj options []))
  ([r-obj
    {:as options
     :keys [avoid]}
    path]
   #_(prn path)
   (let [relevant-names (some->> r-obj
                                 r.base/names
                                 r->clj
                                 (filter (complement avoid)))]
     (cond
       ;;
       ;; a named list or a ggproto object
       (seq relevant-names) (->> relevant-names
                                 (map (fn [nam]
                                        [(keyword nam) (-> r-obj
                                                           (r$ nam)
                                                           (ggolot->clj options
                                                                        (conj path nam)))]))
                                 (into {}))
       ;;
       ;; a ggproto method
       (-> r-obj
           r.base/class
           r->clj
           first
           (= "ggproto_method"))
       :ggproto-method
       ;;
       ;; an unnamed list
       (-> r-obj
           r.base/is-list
           r->clj
           first)
       (-> r-obj
           r.base/length
           r->clj
           first
           range
           (->> (mapv (fn [i]
                        (prn [path (inc i)])
                        (-> r-obj
                            (r/brabra (inc i))
                            (ggolot->clj options
                                         (conj path [i])))))))
       ;;
       (r.base/is-atomic r-obj) (try (r->clj r-obj)
                                     (catch Exception e
                                       (-> r-obj println with-out-str)))
       :else r-obj))))

In the conversion, we avoid some big parts of the structure, e.g., the "plot_env" member. We also do no report the toplevel "data" member, which is simply the dataset. For example:

(-> "(ggplot(mpg, aes(cty, hwy))
         + geom_point())"
    r
    (ggolot->clj {:avoid #{"plot_env"}})
    (dissoc :data))


{:layers
 [{:aes_params [],
   :stat {:compute_layer :ggproto-method, :super :ggproto-method},
   :show.legend [nil],
   :mapping nil,
   :super :ggproto-method,
   :inherit.aes [true],
   :geom_params {:na.rm [false]},
   :geom
   {:non_missing_aes ["size" "shape" "colour"],
    :draw_key :ggproto-method,
    :default_aes
    {:shape [19.0],
     :colour ["black"],
     :size [1.5],
     :fill [nil],
     :alpha [nil],
     :stroke [0.5]},
    :super :ggproto-method,
    :required_aes ["x" "y"],
    :draw_panel :ggproto-method},
   :stat_params {:na.rm [false]},
   :constructor [geom_point],
   :position {:compute_layer :ggproto-method, :super :ggproto-method},
   :data []}],
 :scales {:scales [], :super :ggproto-method},
 :mapping {:x [~ cty], :y [~ hwy]},
 :theme [],
 :coordinates
 {:expand [true],
  :clip ["on"],
  :limits {:x nil, :y nil},
  :super :ggproto-method,
  :default [true]},
 :facet {:shrink [true], :super :ggproto-method},
 :labels {:x ["cty"], :y ["hwy"]}}

title: 3  Exploring ggplot - DRAFT
text:
3.4 Exlploring a few plots
Let us explore and compare a few plots this way:

(defn h4 [title]
  (kind/hiccup [:h3 title]))


(defn ggplot-summary [r-code]
  (let [plot (r r-code)
        clj (-> plot
                (ggolot->clj {:avoid #{"plot_env"}})
                (dissoc :data))]
    (kind/fragment
     [(h4 "R code")
      (kind/md
       (format "\n```\n%s\n```\n"
               r-code))
      (h4 "plot")
      (-> plot
          plotting/plot->buffered-image)
      (h4 "clj data")
      (kind/pprint clj)])))


3.4.1 A scatterplot

(ggplot-summary
 "(ggplot(mpg, aes(cty, hwy))
         + geom_point())")
